nodes.text: Increasing sleep among low-income urban adults causally affects economic outcomes, cognition, and well-being
Objective measurement using wrist actigraphy reveals severe sleep deprivation and low sleep efficiency among low-income adults in Chennai
Randomized controlled trial (N=452) with actigraphy, bundled night-sleep interventions (devices+encouragement or devices+incentives), and a cross-randomized workplace nap opportunity
Night-sleep treatments increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes per night on average by inducing more time in bed, not by improving sleep efficiency
Nighttime sleep increases produced no detectable improvements in cognition, productivity, decision making, or psychological well-being and led to small decreases in labor supply and earnings

Afternoon workplace naps increased daytime sleep by about 14 minutes and significantly improved an overall outcome index (0.12 SD), with positive effects on productivity, psychological well-being, and cognitive measures of attention, but reduced work time due to the nap period

Instrumental-variable analysis indicates per-minute effects of nap sleep on the overall index and several families of outcomes are more positive than per-minute nighttime sleep (differences statistically significant for several outcomes)

Experts (surveyed sleep scientists and economists) predicted sizable economic gains from a 30-minute increase in night sleep, including a 7% work-output increase, but these predictions were strongly rejected by the RCT results
Baseline descriptive evidence: average 5.5â€“5.6 hours asleep per night, ~8 hours in bed, ~70% sleep efficiency, ~30 awakenings/night; self-reports overestimate hours asleep

Opportunity-cost channel: increasing nighttime sleep mainly by increasing time in bed reduced available daytime hours for work, explaining part of null or negative effects on earnings and labor supply

The lack of positive effects from increased night sleep may reflect (a) low marginal returns for modest increases in sleep in the field versus extreme lab deprivation experiments, and/or (b) low sleep quality (low efficiency) limiting returns to additional sleep

Possible mechanisms for nap benefits include better sleep quality in a comfortable office environment and beneficial timing (mid-afternoon circadian dip), but timing versus quality cannot be separated in this study

Conclusions and policy implications: (i) nudges and incentives can raise sleep duration but not necessarily sleep quality; (ii) short workplace naps can yield meaningful cognitive, productivity, and well-being gains despite foregone work time; (iii) caution is warranted when extrapolating laboratory sleep results or expert priors to field settings

Limitations: short treatment horizon (~3 weeks), single urban context (Chennai), bundled night interventions (devices+tips+incentives) limiting attribution, and insufficient power to fully resolve heterogeneity or long-run health effects
